subNodes.conversationText: root
"You just left! Go do something."
"Eldest Lady mentioned I could eat and rest here."
"I have nothing to give a young witch who steps outside for one second and comes back in the next. Come back this afternoon. I can give you something to eat then."
"Very well. Apologies."
"I had questions for you."
"I have nothing to say to a young witch who steps outside for one second and comes back the next. Come back this afternoon. I can give you something to eat then."
"Very well. Apologies."
"Very well. Apologies."
Middle One muttered nonsense and sang scraps of old songs but wouldn't say a word more to <FirstName>.
[End.]
Middle One muttered nonsense and sang scraps of old songs and tried to ignore <FirstName>.
"A spirit of the woods told me something interesting."

Middle One stared.

"Oh?"
<FirstName> left the older witch alone.
"There you are. Sit down. I made some food for you."
<FirstName> complied.

Middle One put down a loaf of hard, black bread, some cheese, and a cup of tea. It had a piney taste, and wondered if it was, in fact, made from pine needles. The other fare was nourishing but by no means delightful.

While ate, Middle One did other tasks around the house. At one point the older witch pulled up a stool and sat across from the younger one.
<FirstName> broke the silence. "I met a spirit in the woods."

Middle One stared.

"Oh?"
"Yes. Does the name 'Wee Malkin' mean anything to you?"

The witch appeared to be thinking something through.

"Wee Malkin? He was a witch. Before Nnenne there was Wee Malkin."
"He was a part of the coven?"
"Yes. You know the Laws. Always three. There was somebody for Nnenne. There had to be. But what could we do? Wee Malkin wanted to leave, so we -- let him leave."
"So you dissolved the coven for him? You did the ritual of breaking?"
"He left, yes."
"What's become of him?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
The young witch had heard enough for now. <He/She> let the subject go.
"What's become of him?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
The young witch had heard enough for now. <He/She> let the subject go.

Middle One showed the young witch to a plain, narrow bed.

The night passed without incident.
[Continue.]
Middle One looked relieved
[End.]
"What's become of him?"
Middle One shifted. "He always wanted more than the coven had to give. The spirits of the wood, on the other hand..."
"The spirits gave him more?"
"More or less," said Middle One.
"But what happened to him? Where is he now?"
"He was a part of the coven?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
The young witch had heard enough for now. <He/She> let the subject go.
"But what happened to him? Where is he now?"
"Wee Malkin? Hmm. Still here, still in the woods."
"Alive or dead?" asked <FirstName>.

Pharaoh squawked. Middle One gave the bird a vicious look.

"Oh, alive! Alive. Certainly not dead. We -- don't talk to him anymore. But he's alive."
The young witch had heard enough for now. <He/She> let the subject go.
"He was a part of the coven?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
"He was a part of the coven?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
The young witch had heard enough for now. <He/She> let the subject go.
"He was a part of the coven?"
The young witch had heard enough for now. <He/She> let the subject go.
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
"Why would we?"
"What's become of him?"
"He was a part of your coven, I suppose?"
"Yes. You know the Laws. The Crone doesn't like even. The Crone doesn't like two. But what could we do? Wee Malkin wanted to leave."
With no answer for this, <FirstName> let the subject go.

Middle One showed the young witch to a plain, narrow bed.

The night passed without incident.
[Continue.]

The older witch was still sleeping when woke up. Knott had become a normal gourd overnight, perhaps to conserve his strength, but he resumed his humanoid form when the young witch got out of bed. helped self to some biscuits and kefir that had been set out for .

Then they left.
Middle One looked relieved
"The spirit told me to mention 'Wee Malkin.' I saw him in a vision."

"A vision?"

Middle One appeared to be thinking something through. "Wee Malkin was a witch. Before Nnenne there was Wee Malkin."
"He was a part of the coven?"
"What's become of him?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
"Who is Wee Malkin, and what are you hiding?"
"Hiding?" Middle One appeared to be thinking something through. "It's no secret. Wee Malkin was a witch. Before Nnenne there was Wee Malkin."
"He was a part of the coven?"
"What's become of him?"
"Why didn't you mention him before?"
"Where did Eldest Lady go?" asked the young witch.
"Hmm? Oh, Eldest Lady? I hate that bitch," said Middle One. "But she's very pleasant in some respects. Not bad to live with."
"I didn't ask for a contradictory account of her disposition," said <FirstName>, "just where she went."
"Hither and thither, I should imagine," said Middle One unhelpfully. The older witch began tidying things up and making other little signs that the meal and conversation were over.
"Before I go... I met a spirit in the woods."
The two sat in silence for the remainder of the meal.
"Pleasant? How so?"

"She never mentions my father's cruelty, a subject painful for me to discuss. In fact, I think it was very wrong of you to bring it up."

At this, Middle One gave the young witch a cold glance and became silent and grave.
<FirstName> broke the silence. "I met a spirit in the woods."
The two sat in silence for the remainder of the meal.
The two sat in silence for the remainder of the meal.
The two sat in silence for the remainder of the meal.
"I'm not hungry."
"No? Then off with you. There's blood to be drawn and plenty of day left to draw it."
"Before I go... I met a spirit in the woods."

Middle One stared.

"Oh?"
"Very well. Apologies."
"Why don't you go look for that blood? No witch should go to bed before midnight. Come back then."
[End.]

"Time for bed? I hope you don't make munching sounds like Eldest Lady."

Sleeping gives you 50 XP.
<FirstName> indicated that <he/she> was ready for bed.

Middle One showed the young witch to a plain, narrow bed.

The night passed without incident.
"There are some things I'd like to discuss first."
Middle One yawned and whined and told <FirstName> it could wait until morning.
<FirstName> agreed.

Middle One showed the young witch to a plain, narrow bed.

The night passed without incident.
[Continue.]

The older witch was still sleeping when woke up. Knott had become a normal gourd overnight, perhaps to conserve his strength, but he resumed his humanoid form when the young witch got out of bed. helped self to some biscuits and kefir that had been set out for .

Then they left.
[End.]
"Fine. But I'm not ready to sleep yet."
"Well I am, and I won't be latching and unlatching the door all night."
<FirstName> relented and agreed to go to bed.

The older witch was still sleeping when woke up. Knott had become a normal gourd overnight, perhaps to conserve his strength, but he resumed his humanoid form when the young witch got out of bed. helped self to some biscuits and kefir that had been set out for .

Then they left.
"Then go to bed, Middle One. I'll stay out tonight."
"I'm not ready to go to bed yet."
"Well I am, and I won't be latching and unlatching the door all night."
Middle One was getting ready for bed and did not want to talk.
[End.]
Middle One pretended not to hear <FirstName>.
[End.]
